texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Land Preparation
texts.text: Land Preparation

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For  rainfed  cotton,  deep  ploughing  once  in  3  years  with  mould  board  plough  or  disc harrow facilitates deep infiltration of water and charging of soil profile with large quantities of water. The land has to be ploughed 2 to 3 times and work with harrow to bring the soil to good tilth. Seeds can be dibbled by maintaining spacing in between plants after running a marker in one or two direction(s).  For irrigated crop, ridges and furrows are to be formed at recommended spacings after deep ploughing.
texts.text: For  rainfed  cotton,  deep  ploughing  once  in  3  years  with  mould  board  plough  or  disc harrow facilitates deep infiltration of water and charging of soil profile with large quantities of water. The land has to be ploughed 2 to 3 times and work with harrow to bring the soil to good tilth. Seeds can be dibbled by maintaining spacing in between plants after running a marker in one or two direction(s).  For irrigated crop, ridges and furrows are to be formed at recommended spacings after deep ploughing.

texts.orig: 2 kg / acre
texts.text: 2 kg / acre

texts.text: 4-5 kg / acre

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Seed Treatment :
texts.text: Seed Treatment :

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For acid delinting, seed should be treated with 80-l00 ml H2 SO4 per kg of seed for 2-3 minutes followed by lime solution and thorough washing with water 2-3 times to make the seed acid  free.    Seed  treatment  with  appropriate  insecticide(s);  imidacloprid  70  WS  @  5  g  /  kg  or thiomethoxam 70 WS @ 4 g / kg or imidacloprid 48 FS@ 9ml/kg or carbosulfan 25 DS @ 40 g/kg of seed. followed by, treatment with Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 10 g / kg or Trichoderma viride or T. harzianum @ 10 g / kg or carbendazim 50 WP @ 2 g / kg or mancozeb 75 WP @ 3 g / kg or captan 50 WP 3 g / kg or thiram 75 WP @ 3 g / kg.
texts.text: For acid delinting, seed should be treated with 80-l00 ml H2 SO4 per kg of seed for 2-3 minutes followed by lime solution and thorough washing with water 2-3 times to make the seed acid  free.    Seed  treatment  with  appropriate  insecticide(s);  imidacloprid  70  WS  @  5  g  /  kg  or thiomethoxam 70 WS @ 4 g / kg or imidacloprid 48 FS@ 9ml/kg or carbosulfan 25 DS @ 40 g/kg of seed. followed by, treatment with Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 10 g / kg or Trichoderma viride or T. harzianum @ 10 g / kg or carbendazim 50 WP @ 2 g / kg or mancozeb 75 WP @ 3 g / kg or captan 50 WP 3 g / kg or thiram 75 WP @ 3 g / kg.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Inter Cropping:
texts.text: Inter Cropping:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Inter cropping with mungbean / urdbean / soybean / cluster bean in 1:2 or 1:3 ratio, and pigeonpea 4:1 or 6:1 or 8:1 ratio.
texts.text: Inter cropping with mungbean / urdbean / soybean / cluster bean in 1:2 or 1:3 ratio, and pigeonpea 4:1 or 6:1 or 8:1 ratio.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Gap filling and Thinning:
texts.text: Gap filling and Thinning:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Gap filling should be done preferably within 10 DAS. Thinning should be done within three weeks after sowing retaining two plants per hill in case of varieties, one plant per hill in case of hybrids.
texts.text: Gap filling should be done preferably within 10 DAS. Thinning should be done within three weeks after sowing retaining two plants per hill in case of varieties, one plant per hill in case of hybrids.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Manures and Fertilizers:
texts.text: Manures and Fertilizers:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Apply FYM @ 4 t / acre (10 cart loads) besides the recommended fertilizers.
texts.text: Apply FYM @ 4 t / acre (10 cart loads) besides the recommended fertilizers.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: For Desi Cotton Varieties:
texts.text: For Desi Cotton Varieties:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 8 N + 8 P2O5 kg/acre. Entire P as basal. N is in two splits at 30 DAS and 60 DAS by pocketing method.
texts.text: 8 N + 8 P2O5 kg/acre. Entire P as basal. N is in two splits at 30 DAS and 60 DAS by pocketing method.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: For American Cotton Varieties:
texts.text: For American Cotton Varieties:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 36 N + 18 P2O5 + 18 K2O kg/acre.  Entire P as basal, N and K in three splits 30, 60 and 90 DAS by pocketing method.
texts.text: 36 N + 18 P2O5 + 18 K2O kg/acre.  Entire P as basal, N and K in three splits 30, 60 and 90 DAS by pocketing method.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: For Conventinol Cotton Hybrids:
texts.text: For Conventinol Cotton Hybrids:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 48 N + 24 P2O5, 24 K2O kg/acre.  Entire P as basal, N and K in three splits 30, 60, 90 DAS by pocketing method.
texts.text: 48 N + 24 P2O5, 24 K2O kg/acre.  Entire P as basal, N and K in three splits 30, 60, 90 DAS by pocketing method.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: For Bt Cotton Hybrids:
texts.text: For Bt Cotton Hybrids:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 25%  excess  N  over  recommended  N  should  be  applied.  The  recommended  N  and  K should be given in 3-4 splits at 20 days interval starting from 20 DAS. Foliar application of 2% urea/ 2% DAP/ 2% KNO3 at flowering and boll development stages.
texts.text: 25%  excess  N  over  recommended  N  should  be  applied.  The  recommended  N  and  K should be given in 3-4 splits at 20 days interval starting from 20 DAS. Foliar application of 2% urea/ 2% DAP/ 2% KNO3 at flowering and boll development stages.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For correcting magnesium, boron and zinc deficiencies, foliar application of MgSO4 @ l% twice at 45 and 75 DAS; Boron @ 0.l5% twice at 60 and 90 DAS; and ZnSO4 @ 0.2% twice at  4-5  days  interval  at  45  DAS  is  recommended.  For  correcting  iron  deficiency  due  to  heavy moisture stress in early crop growth stage, foliar application of 0.5% FeSO4 along with citric acid should be done twice at weekly interval.
texts.text: For correcting magnesium, boron and zinc deficiencies, foliar application of MgSO4 @ l% twice at 45 and 75 DAS; Boron @ 0.l5% twice at 60 and 90 DAS; and ZnSO4 @ 0.2% twice at  4-5  days  interval  at  45  DAS  is  recommended.  For  correcting  iron  deficiency  due  to  heavy moisture stress in early crop growth stage, foliar application of 0.5% FeSO4 along with citric acid should be done twice at weekly interval.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Weed Management:
texts.text: Weed Management:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Spray  pendimethalin @  1.5 to 2.0 l/acre immediately or within 48 hours of sowing. Inter cultivation with tyned harrow and blade harrow 2-3 times upto 90 DAS. For control of grasses and broad leaved weeds post emergence spray of quizalofopethyl @ 400 ml/acre and pyrithiobac sodium  @  250  ml  /  acre  is  recommended  at  25-30  DAS.  Post  emergence  directed  spray  of parquat @ 5.0 ml/l of water or glyphosate 10.0 ml + 10.0 g of urea or ammonium sulphate/l of water  is  recommended  for  control  of  the  weeds  in  the  cotton  crop,  where  inter-cultivation  or manual weeding is not possible due to unfavourable weather conditions.
texts.text: Spray  pendimethalin @  1.5 to 2.0 l/acre immediately or within 48 hours of sowing. Inter cultivation with tyned harrow and blade harrow 2-3 times upto 90 DAS. For control of grasses and broad leaved weeds post emergence spray of quizalofopethyl @ 400 ml/acre and pyrithiobac sodium  @  250  ml  /  acre  is  recommended  at  25-30  DAS.  Post  emergence  directed  spray  of parquat @ 5.0 ml/l of water or glyphosate 10.0 ml + 10.0 g of urea or ammonium sulphate/l of water  is  recommended  for  control  of  the  weeds  in  the  cotton  crop,  where  inter-cultivation  or manual weeding is not possible due to unfavourable weather conditions.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Irrigation: Generally cotton crop requires 2-4 irrigations depending upon the soil type.
texts.text: Irrigation: Generally cotton crop requires 2-4 irrigations depending upon the soil type.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Pest Management in Cotton
texts.text: Pest Management in Cotton

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Management of Sucking Pests in cotton:
texts.text: Management of Sucking Pests in cotton:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Grow sucking pest tolerant / resistant varieties / hybrids.
texts.text: Grow sucking pest tolerant / resistant varieties / hybrids.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Seed treatment with imidacloprid 70 WS 5.0 g /kg or thiamethoxam 70 WS 4.0 g / kg or imidacloprid 48 FS @ 9.0 ml/kg or carbosulfan 25 DS @ 40.0 g/kg of seed, gives early protection against sucking pests.
texts.text: Seed treatment with imidacloprid 70 WS 5.0 g /kg or thiamethoxam 70 WS 4.0 g / kg or imidacloprid 48 FS @ 9.0 ml/kg or carbosulfan 25 DS @ 40.0 g/kg of seed, gives early protection against sucking pests.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Growing of intercrops like mungbean or urdbean or soybean or cluster bean  in 1:2 or 1:3 ratio  will  facilitate  the  buildup  of  native  natural  enemy  populations  that  in  turn  keep sucking pests under check
texts.text: Growing of intercrops like mungbean or urdbean or soybean or cluster bean  in 1:2 or 1:3 ratio  will  facilitate  the  buildup  of  native  natural  enemy  populations  that  in  turn  keep sucking pests under check

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Growing of cowpea as bund crop is advantageous to encourage predacious insects like coccinellids, syrphids and chrysopids
texts.text: Growing of cowpea as bund crop is advantageous to encourage predacious insects like coccinellids, syrphids and chrysopids

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. Maize or  sorghum  or  pearlmillet  grown  as  barrier  crops  in  the  border  prevents  spread from neighbouring fields.
texts.text: Maize or  sorghum  or  pearlmillet  grown  as  barrier  crops  in  the  border  prevents  spread from neighbouring fields.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Stem  application  at  30  &  45  DAS  with  monocrotophos  (1:4)  and  at  60  DAS  with imidacloprid  (1:20)  for  protecting  the  crop  from  early  season  sucking  pests  is  highly effective.
texts.text: Stem  application  at  30  &  45  DAS  with  monocrotophos  (1:4)  and  at  60  DAS  with imidacloprid  (1:20)  for  protecting  the  crop  from  early  season  sucking  pests  is  highly effective.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 7. Setting up of yellow sticky traps @ 10 per acre for monitoring whitefly incidence.
texts.text: Setting up of yellow sticky traps @ 10 per acre for monitoring whitefly incidence.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 8. Economic Threshold Level (ETL) for sucking pests on cotton is presented hereunder :
texts.text: Economic Threshold Level (ETL) for sucking pests on cotton is presented hereunder :

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 9. ETL based application of insecticides
texts.text: 9. ETL based application of insecticides

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Leafhoppers / aphids / thrips  -   Monocrotophos 36 SL @ 1.6 ml/l or Acephate 75 SP @1.5g/l or Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 0.4 ml/l or Acetamiprid 20 SP @ 0.2 g/l or Thiamethoxam 25 WG @ 0.2 g/l or Fipronil 5 SC @ 2.0 ml/l Whitefly -   Triazophos 40 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or Profenophos 50 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or Diafenthiuron 50% WP @ 1.25 g/l or NSKE @ 5% (extract from 10.0 kg of Neem Powder/acre) Red mite -   Wettable sulphur 80 WP @ 3.0 g/l or Dicofol 18.5 SC @ 5.0 ml/l
texts.text: Leafhoppers / aphids / thrips  -   Monocrotophos 36 SL @ 1.6 ml/l or Acephate 75 SP @1.5g/l or Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 0.4 ml/l or Acetamiprid 20 SP @ 0.2 g/l or Thiamethoxam 25 WG @ 0.2 g/l or Fipronil 5 SC @ 2.0 ml/l Whitefly -   Triazophos 40 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or Profenophos 50 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or Diafenthiuron 50% WP @ 1.25 g/l or NSKE @ 5% (extract from 10.0 kg of Neem Powder/acre) Red mite -   Wettable sulphur 80 WP @ 3.0 g/l or Dicofol 18.5 SC @ 5.0 ml/l

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Insecticide Resistance Management Strategies to manage cotton pests in Bt-cotton
texts.text: Insecticide Resistance Management Strategies to manage cotton pests in Bt-cotton

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Early Sucking Pest Window 1: 0-60 DAS: No foliar spray upto 60 DAS.
texts.text: Early Sucking Pest Window 1: 0-60 DAS: No foliar spray upto 60 DAS.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Cultivation of sucking pest tolerant varieties / hybrids
texts.text:  Cultivation of sucking pest tolerant varieties / hybrids

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Use dual gene, such as Bollgard II resistant (Cry I Ac + Cry 2 Ab)
texts.text:  Use dual gene, such as Bollgard II resistant (Cry I Ac + Cry 2 Ab)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Raising densely planted border rows of maize / sorghum / pearlmillet / pigeonpea
texts.text:  Raising densely planted border rows of maize / sorghum / pearlmillet / pigeonpea

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Mechanical  control  of Parthenium and Abutilon weeds  to  avoid  build  up  of  initial mealy bug inoculum.
texts.text:  Mechanical  control  of Parthenium and Abutilon weeds  to  avoid  build  up  of  initial mealy bug inoculum.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Stem application of monocrotophos at 30 and 45, and imidachloprid at 60 DAS.
texts.text:  Stem application of monocrotophos at 30 and 45, and imidachloprid at 60 DAS.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Neem oil sprays @ 1.0 l/acre + detergent powder @ 1.0 g or sandovit @ 0.5 ml or Teepol 0.5 ml/lt. for the control of whitefly.
texts.text:  Neem oil sprays @ 1.0 l/acre + detergent powder @ 1.0 g or sandovit @ 0.5 ml or Teepol 0.5 ml/lt. for the control of whitefly.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Window 2: 60-90 DAS : Initial boll worm infestation. Mostly eggs and young larvae: Biological and bio-pesticide window.
texts.text: Window 2: 60-90 DAS : Initial boll worm infestation. Mostly eggs and young larvae: Biological and bio-pesticide window.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Hand picking of Helicoverpa and Spodoptera larvae, and egg masses of Spodoptera .
texts.text:  Hand picking of Helicoverpa and Spodoptera larvae, and egg masses of Spodoptera .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  One spray of novaluron @1.0 ml/lt or lufenuron @1.25ml/lt for the control of Spodoptera on need basis only.
texts.text:  One spray of novaluron @1.0 ml/lt or lufenuron @1.25ml/lt for the control of Spodoptera on need basis only.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Installation of yellow sticky traps @ 10.0 / acre for monitoring of the whitefly.
texts.text:  Installation of yellow sticky traps @ 10.0 / acre for monitoring of the whitefly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Application of 5% NSKE for bollworm and whitefly infestation.
texts.text:  Application of 5% NSKE for bollworm and whitefly infestation.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  No spray against minor lepidopteran pests.
texts.text:  No spray against minor lepidopteran pests.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Follow  Integrated  Nutrient  Management practices including foliar spray of  nutrients  to reduce leaf reddening.
texts.text:  Follow  Integrated  Nutrient  Management practices including foliar spray of  nutrients  to reduce leaf reddening.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Neonicotinoids  like  imidacloprid  or  acetamiprid  or  thiomethaxam  for  the  control  of sucking pests.
texts.text:  Neonicotinoids  like  imidacloprid  or  acetamiprid  or  thiomethaxam  for  the  control  of sucking pests.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Spinosad or emamectin benzoate only on non-Bt cotton.
texts.text:  Spinosad or emamectin benzoate only on non-Bt cotton.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Window 3: 90-120 DAS: Peak Boll worm infestation.
texts.text: Window 3: 90-120 DAS: Peak Boll worm infestation.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  One application of chlorpyriphos or quinalphos or thiodicarb or spinosad on conventional or Bt-cotton plants showing flared up squares.
texts.text:  One application of chlorpyriphos or quinalphos or thiodicarb or spinosad on conventional or Bt-cotton plants showing flared up squares.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Poison bait (10 kg rice bran +2.0 kg jaggery + chlorpyriphos 500-700 ml or thiodicarb 250-300 g) for the control of grown up larvae of spodoptera .
texts.text:  Poison bait (10 kg rice bran +2.0 kg jaggery + chlorpyriphos 500-700 ml or thiodicarb 250-300 g) for the control of grown up larvae of spodoptera .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Window 4: >120 DAS : Boll worms & Mealy bugs.
texts.text: Window 4: >120 DAS : Boll worms & Mealy bugs.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  In case of minimum infestation of mealy bug, uprooting and destroying of infested plants.
texts.text:  In case of minimum infestation of mealy bug, uprooting and destroying of infested plants.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Surrounding weeds especially, Parthenium are sprayed with chlorpyriphos and destroyed subsequently.
texts.text:  Surrounding weeds especially, Parthenium are sprayed with chlorpyriphos and destroyed subsequently.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  In severe mealy bug infestation drenching the affected stems with malathion @ 2.0 ml/l or buprofezin @ 2.0 ml/l or acephate @ 2.0 g/l along with sticky agents.
texts.text:  In severe mealy bug infestation drenching the affected stems with malathion @ 2.0 ml/l or buprofezin @ 2.0 ml/l or acephate @ 2.0 g/l along with sticky agents.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Insecticides  like  chlorpyriphos,  quinalphos,  profenophos,  carbaryl  are  used  in  case  of severe economic damage due to mealy bug.
texts.text:  Insecticides  like  chlorpyriphos,  quinalphos,  profenophos,  carbaryl  are  used  in  case  of severe economic damage due to mealy bug.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Need based use of insecticides: Spraying of persistent insecticides like thiodicarb 75 WP @ 1.5 g/l or quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 2.5 ml/l at 15 days interval.
texts.text:  Need based use of insecticides: Spraying of persistent insecticides like thiodicarb 75 WP @ 1.5 g/l or quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 2.5 ml/l at 15 days interval.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Hand  picking  of  surviving  bollworm  larvae  from  Bt-cotton  fields  and  destruction  of residual pupae by deep ploughing immediately after harvest.
texts.text:  Hand  picking  of  surviving  bollworm  larvae  from  Bt-cotton  fields  and  destruction  of residual pupae by deep ploughing immediately after harvest.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Integrated Pest Management in Cotton:
texts.text: Integrated Pest Management in Cotton:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Avoid monocroping of cotton.
texts.text: Avoid monocroping of cotton.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Application of chemical fertilizer as supplement to organic or biological fertilizers as per the recommended doses.
texts.text: Application of chemical fertilizer as supplement to organic or biological fertilizers as per the recommended doses.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Growing  intercrops/strip crops/barrier crops with greengram, blackgram, soybean cowpea, clusterbean, groundnut, foxtail millet and coriander were found better intercrops in increasing the effectiveness of natural enemies like coccinellids, syrphids, chrysopids, spiders, Trichogrammids , Apantelids etc. Growing fodder sorghum or maize as barrier crops and castor as ovipositional trap crop with in the cotton was also found to be more advantageous to manage the pests of cotton.
texts.text: Growing  intercrops/strip crops/barrier crops with greengram, blackgram, soybean cowpea, clusterbean, groundnut, foxtail millet and coriander were found better intercrops in increasing the effectiveness of natural enemies like coccinellids, syrphids, chrysopids, spiders, Trichogrammids , Apantelids etc. Growing fodder sorghum or maize as barrier crops and castor as ovipositional trap crop with in the cotton was also found to be more advantageous to manage the pests of cotton.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Seed treatment with recommended insecticides and fungicides.
texts.text: Seed treatment with recommended insecticides and fungicides.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. Stem application of Monocrotophos at 30 and 45, and imidacloprid at 60 DAS.
texts.text: Stem application of Monocrotophos at 30 and 45, and imidacloprid at 60 DAS.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Monitoring  pests  by  using  light,  sticky  and  pheromone  traps.  The  adults  monitoring should  be  supported  by  egg  and  larval  monitoring  following  sequential  sampling technique at frequent intervals in case of boll worms.
texts.text: Monitoring  pests  by  using  light,  sticky  and  pheromone  traps.  The  adults  monitoring should  be  supported  by  egg  and  larval  monitoring  following  sequential  sampling technique at frequent intervals in case of boll worms.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 7. Bird  perches  should  be  arranged  @  10  per  acre  for  encouraging  bird  predation  on bollworm larvae.
texts.text: Bird  perches  should  be  arranged  @  10  per  acre  for  encouraging  bird  predation  on bollworm larvae.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 8. The buildup of broad spectrum predators viz. , spiders, coccinellids and chrysopids should be synchronised in other cultural operations. Release of Trichogramma egg  parasite  @ 50,000/ha and Chrysopa egg larval predator @ l0000/ha, should be done as soon as the first brood of bollworms are noticed.
texts.text: The buildup of broad spectrum predators viz. , spiders, coccinellids and chrysopids should be synchronised in other cultural operations. Release of Trichogramma egg  parasite  @ 50,000/ha and Chrysopa egg larval predator @ l0000/ha, should be done as soon as the first brood of bollworms are noticed.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 9. Topping  of  cotton  plants  when  maximum  egg  laying  of Helicoverpa  armigera is noticed (October-November months).
texts.text: Topping  of  cotton  plants  when  maximum  egg  laying  of Helicoverpa  armigera is noticed (October-November months).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 10. Application of HNPV @ 500 LE/ha or neem seed kernel extract (5%) in synchrony with early larvae of Helicoverpa . Neem oil formulation to manage initial whitefly.
texts.text: Application of HNPV @ 500 LE/ha or neem seed kernel extract (5%) in synchrony with early larvae of Helicoverpa . Neem oil formulation to manage initial whitefly.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 11. ETLs for Bollworms
texts.text: 11. ETLs for Bollworms

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 12. Poison bait (10.0 kg of rice bran + 2.0 kg jaggery + 500-750 ml of chlorpyriphos or 250300 g of thiodicarb) for the control of grownup larvae of Spodoptera .
texts.text: Poison bait (10.0 kg of rice bran + 2.0 kg jaggery + 500-750 ml of chlorpyriphos or 250300 g of thiodicarb) for the control of grownup larvae of Spodoptera .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 13. Resorting  to  chemical  insecticides  for  the  control  of  leafhoppers  spray  monocrotophos 36  SL  @  1.6  ml/l  or  acephate  75  SP  @  1.5  g/l  or  fipronil  5%  SC  @  2.0  ml/l  or imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 0.4 ml/l or acetamiprid 20 SP @ 0.2 g/l or thiamethoxam 25 WG @  0.2  g/l  or  flonicamid  50  WG  @  0.3  g/l.  For  the  management  of  whitefly  spray triazophos 40 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or  profenophos 50 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or diafenthiuron 50 WP @ 1.25 g/l or neem seed kernel extract @ 5% or neem oil @ 5.0 ml/l; for the control of Helicoverpa armigera spray quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or acephate 75 SP @ 1.5 g/l or indoxacarb 14.5 SC @ 1.0 ml/l or thiodicarb 75 WP @  1.5  g/l  or  spinosad  45  SC  @  0.3  ml/l  or  flubendiamide  48  SC  @  0.3  ml/l  or chlorantraniliprole  18.5  SC  @  0.3  ml/l.  For  managing  red  spider  mites,  application  of wettable sulphur 80 WP @ 3.0 g/l or dicofol 18.5 SC @ 5.0 ml/l. Similarly if mealy bugs spread in patches to alarming level spray acephate 75 SP @ 2.0 g/l or profenophos 50 EC @ 3.0 ml/l mixing with sandovit or teepol.
texts.text: Resorting  to  chemical  insecticides  for  the  control  of  leafhoppers  spray  monocrotophos 36  SL  @  1.6  ml/l  or  acephate  75  SP  @  1.5  g/l  or  fipronil  5%  SC  @  2.0  ml/l  or imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 0.4 ml/l or acetamiprid 20 SP @ 0.2 g/l or thiamethoxam 25 WG @  0.2  g/l  or  flonicamid  50  WG  @  0.3  g/l.  For  the  management  of  whitefly  spray triazophos 40 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or  profenophos 50 EC @ 2.0 ml/l or diafenthiuron 50 WP @ 1.25 g/l or neem seed kernel extract @ 5% or neem oil @ 5.0 ml/l; for the control of Helicoverpa armigera spray quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or acephate 75 SP @ 1.5 g/l or indoxacarb 14.5 SC @ 1.0 ml/l or thiodicarb 75 WP @  1.5  g/l  or  spinosad  45  SC  @  0.3  ml/l  or  flubendiamide  48  SC  @  0.3  ml/l  or chlorantraniliprole  18.5  SC  @  0.3  ml/l.  For  managing  red  spider  mites,  application  of wettable sulphur 80 WP @ 3.0 g/l or dicofol 18.5 SC @ 5.0 ml/l. Similarly if mealy bugs spread in patches to alarming level spray acephate 75 SP @ 2.0 g/l or profenophos 50 EC @ 3.0 ml/l mixing with sandovit or teepol.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 14. Removal  of  cotton  stubbles  after  last  picking  without  opting  for  ratoon  crop  or prolonging the crop growth with irrigations and fertilizer applications. This is essential to break the cycles of problem pests in the system as a whole
texts.text: Removal  of  cotton  stubbles  after  last  picking  without  opting  for  ratoon  crop  or prolonging the crop growth with irrigations and fertilizer applications. This is essential to break the cycles of problem pests in the system as a whole

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Mealy bug management in Cotton
texts.text: Mealy bug management in Cotton

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Adopt crop rotation
texts.text:  Adopt crop rotation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Removal  and  burning  of  alternate  weed  hosts    like Parthenium , Abutilon etc.in  the vicinity of cotton crop
texts.text:  Removal  and  burning  of  alternate  weed  hosts    like Parthenium , Abutilon etc.in  the vicinity of cotton crop

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Control mealy bug population on the alternate crop hosts during on and off season
texts.text:  Control mealy bug population on the alternate crop hosts during on and off season

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Stem application of monocrotophos diluted with water in 1:4 ratio during vegetative and early  reproductive  stage  of  the  cotton  crop  at  30,  45  and  60  DAS  as  a  prophylactic measure.
texts.text:  Stem application of monocrotophos diluted with water in 1:4 ratio during vegetative and early  reproductive  stage  of  the  cotton  crop  at  30,  45  and  60  DAS  as  a  prophylactic measure.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Monitoring the initial infestation of mealy bug, particularly on border plants and shaded areas for timing of control measures.
texts.text:  Monitoring the initial infestation of mealy bug, particularly on border plants and shaded areas for timing of control measures.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Need based spraying of insecticides, triazophos 40 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or prophenophos 50 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or acephate 75 WP 2.0 g/l mixed with stickers like triton or sandovit or teapot etc @ 1ml/l of spray fluid
texts.text:  Need based spraying of insecticides, triazophos 40 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or prophenophos 50 EC @ 3.0 ml/l or acephate 75 WP 2.0 g/l mixed with stickers like triton or sandovit or teapot etc @ 1ml/l of spray fluid

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Spot application of insecticides is desirable when the infestation is confined to isolated pockets in the field.
texts.text:  Spot application of insecticides is desirable when the infestation is confined to isolated pockets in the field.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Removal and destruction by burning of heavily infested dried / dead cotton plants may be taken up to arrest further spread of the pest incidence.
texts.text:  Removal and destruction by burning of heavily infested dried / dead cotton plants may be taken up to arrest further spread of the pest incidence.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:  Removal and burning of left over cotton stubbles after harvesting.
texts.text:  Removal and burning of left over cotton stubbles after harvesting.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Management strategies for pink bollworm:
texts.text: Management strategies for pink bollworm:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Grow early maturing varieties so that the cotton bolls mature before the heavy population of pink bollworm builds up.
texts.text: Grow early maturing varieties so that the cotton bolls mature before the heavy population of pink bollworm builds up.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Avoid staggered sowing in an area and take up timely sowings.
texts.text: Avoid staggered sowing in an area and take up timely sowings.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Use of acid delinted seed.
texts.text: Use of acid delinted seed.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Adopting efficient and timely agronomic practices such as use of organic manures and recommended doses of 'N' fertilizers only.
texts.text: Adopting efficient and timely agronomic practices such as use of organic manures and recommended doses of 'N' fertilizers only.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. Keep the crop free from weeds.
texts.text: Keep the crop free from weeds.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Regular monitoring for pest build up with field scouting and pheromone traps.
texts.text: Regular monitoring for pest build up with field scouting and pheromone traps.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 7. Destroy pink bollworm larvae in rosette flowers and also through periodical removal of dropped squares, dried flowers and pre-matured bolls, to suppress pest population in the initial stage.
texts.text: Destroy pink bollworm larvae in rosette flowers and also through periodical removal of dropped squares, dried flowers and pre-matured bolls, to suppress pest population in the initial stage.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 8. Avoid ratooning and summer cotton.
texts.text: Avoid ratooning and summer cotton.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 9. Allow cattle, sheep and goats to graze upon immature green bolls and attacked bolls after final picking to prevent carry-over of the pest to the next season.
texts.text: Allow cattle, sheep and goats to graze upon immature green bolls and attacked bolls after final picking to prevent carry-over of the pest to the next season.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 10. Prompt removal and destruction of cotton stubbles to prevent carryover of pest to next season.
texts.text: Prompt removal and destruction of cotton stubbles to prevent carryover of pest to next season.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 11. Restrict the movement of cotton seed from other areas/states
texts.text: Restrict the movement of cotton seed from other areas/states

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 12. Need based use of insecticides: Spraying of persistent insecticides like thiodicarb 75 WP @ 1.5 g/l or quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 2.5 ml/l at 15 days interval.
texts.text: Need based use of insecticides: Spraying of persistent insecticides like thiodicarb 75 WP @ 1.5 g/l or quinalphos 25 EC @ 2.5 ml/l or chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 2.5 ml/l at 15 days interval.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Management of Cotton Diseases:
texts.text: Management of Cotton Diseases:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Bacterial  blight: Angular  leaf  spots  develop  and  spread  through  veins  causing  vein  blight. Under  severe  conditions  disease  spreads  to  branches  causing  black  arm.  Dark  green  spots develop on bolls which turn black and bolls rot.
texts.text: Bacterial  blight: Angular  leaf  spots  develop  and  spread  through  veins  causing  vein  blight. Under  severe  conditions  disease  spreads  to  branches  causing  black  arm.  Dark  green  spots develop on bolls which turn black and bolls rot.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Control:  Seed  treatment  with Pseudomonas fluorescens @  10.0g/kg  seed;  spraying  copper  oxy chloride  3.0  g/l  +  streptocycline  100  mg/l  starting  from  50  days  after  sowing,  2-3  times,  at fortnightly intervals.
texts.text: Control:  Seed  treatment  with Pseudomonas fluorescens @  10.0g/kg  seed;  spraying  copper  oxy chloride  3.0  g/l  +  streptocycline  100  mg/l  starting  from  50  days  after  sowing,  2-3  times,  at fortnightly intervals.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Alternaria leaf spot: Brown spots with concentric rings develop on leaves, join together and dry; defoliation occurs. Lesions on stem extend and break.
texts.text: Alternaria leaf spot: Brown spots with concentric rings develop on leaves, join together and dry; defoliation occurs. Lesions on stem extend and break.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Helminthosporium leaf spot: Light brown spots with ashy centres and red margins
texts.text: Helminthosporium leaf spot: Light brown spots with ashy centres and red margins

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Cercospora leaf spot : Dark brown circular spots with white centres and purple margins develop on leaves.
texts.text: Cercospora leaf spot : Dark brown circular spots with white centres and purple margins develop on leaves.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Control: For the control of leaf spots seed treatment with P. fluorescens @ 10.0 g or carbendazim 2.0g  or  thiram  3.0g  or  vitavax  2.0  g/kg  of  seed;  spraying  copper  oxy  chloride  3.0  g/l  or mancozeb 3.0 g/l or propiconazole 1.0 ml/l or captan + hexaconazole 1.0 g/l starting from 50 DAS, 2-3 times, at fortnightly intervals.
texts.text: Control: For the control of leaf spots seed treatment with P. fluorescens @ 10.0 g or carbendazim 2.0g  or  thiram  3.0g  or  vitavax  2.0  g/kg  of  seed;  spraying  copper  oxy  chloride  3.0  g/l  or mancozeb 3.0 g/l or propiconazole 1.0 ml/l or captan + hexaconazole 1.0 g/l starting from 50 DAS, 2-3 times, at fortnightly intervals.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Grey mildew: Angular, white, powdery spots develop on leaves, spread and defoliation occurs. Control: Spraying water soluble sulphur 3.0 g/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l, 2-3 times, at 10-15 days interval.
texts.text: Grey mildew: Angular, white, powdery spots develop on leaves, spread and defoliation occurs. Control: Spraying water soluble sulphur 3.0 g/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l, 2-3 times, at 10-15 days interval.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Rust: Yellowish brown to reddish brown pustules develop on both sides of the leaves.
texts.text: Rust: Yellowish brown to reddish brown pustules develop on both sides of the leaves.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Control: Spraying water soluble sulphur 3.0 g/l or tridemorph 1.0 ml/l or propiconazole 1.0 ml/l, starting from 75 DAS, 2-3 times, at fortnightly intervals.
texts.text: Control: Spraying water soluble sulphur 3.0 g/l or tridemorph 1.0 ml/l or propiconazole 1.0 ml/l, starting from 75 DAS, 2-3 times, at fortnightly intervals.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Boll Rots: Dark spots or lesions develop on bolls.
texts.text: Boll Rots: Dark spots or lesions develop on bolls.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Control: Spray copper oxy chloride 3.0 g/l + streptocycline 100 mg/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l or dithane M-45 2.5 g/l.
texts.text: Control: Spray copper oxy chloride 3.0 g/l + streptocycline 100 mg/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l or dithane M-45 2.5 g/l.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Root  rot: Sudden  death  of  young  plants  in  patches,  roots  become  sticky  and  bark  shreds  in grown up plants.
texts.text: Root  rot: Sudden  death  of  young  plants  in  patches,  roots  become  sticky  and  bark  shreds  in grown up plants.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Fusarium  wilt: Damping  off  symptoms  at  seedling  stage,  lower  leaves  wilt  early  and  drop. Brown streaks are visible in split open branches or stems, sometimes with black spores.
texts.text: Fusarium  wilt: Damping  off  symptoms  at  seedling  stage,  lower  leaves  wilt  early  and  drop. Brown streaks are visible in split open branches or stems, sometimes with black spores.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Verticillium wilt: Interveinal chorosis and dark lesions develop on leaves with appearance of tiger  stripes,  brown  discolouration  is  visible  in  split  open  stems,  branches  and  also  inside  the bark, plants die in the centre of infected patch.
texts.text: Verticillium wilt: Interveinal chorosis and dark lesions develop on leaves with appearance of tiger  stripes,  brown  discolouration  is  visible  in  split  open  stems,  branches  and  also  inside  the bark, plants die in the centre of infected patch.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Control:  Seed  treatment  with Trichoderma  viride @  10.0  g  or P.  fluorescens @  10.0  g  or carbendazim 2.0 g or thiram 3.0 g or vitavax 2.0 g/kg of seed; soil application of T.  viride or P. fluorescens @ 1.0 kg/acre developed in 100.0 kg FYM or vermicompost along with 20.0 kg of neem  cake.    Balanced  Nitrogen  application  and  correcting  micronutrient  deficiencies.  Soil drenching at the base of infected plants with copper oxy chloride 3.0 g/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l or benomyl 1.0 g/l.
texts.text: Control:  Seed  treatment  with Trichoderma  viride @  10.0  g  or P.  fluorescens @  10.0  g  or carbendazim 2.0 g or thiram 3.0 g or vitavax 2.0 g/kg of seed; soil application of T.  viride or P. fluorescens @ 1.0 kg/acre developed in 100.0 kg FYM or vermicompost along with 20.0 kg of neem  cake.    Balanced  Nitrogen  application  and  correcting  micronutrient  deficiencies.  Soil drenching at the base of infected plants with copper oxy chloride 3.0 g/l or carbendazim 1.0 g/l or benomyl 1.0 g/l.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Harvesting :
texts.text: Harvesting :

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. Kapas from fully opened bolls should be collected during cooler times of the day.
texts.text: Kapas from fully opened bolls should be collected during cooler times of the day.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Kapas picked should be free from debris like dried leaves, dried bracts etc.
texts.text: Kapas picked should be free from debris like dried leaves, dried bracts etc.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Kapas from the first and last pickings should not be mixed with middle pickings, which are of better quality.
texts.text: Kapas from the first and last pickings should not be mixed with middle pickings, which are of better quality.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Kapas damaged by bollworms should be picked separately.
texts.text: Kapas damaged by bollworms should be picked separately.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. The cleaned kapas is to be graded and stored in heaps or in gunny boras in dry and well ventilated godowns.
texts.text: The cleaned kapas is to be graded and stored in heaps or in gunny boras in dry and well ventilated godowns.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Post-harvest Technology:
texts.text: Post-harvest Technology:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. It  is  essential  that  proper  care  is  taken  at  various  stages  of  handling  and  processing  to ensure  that  the  inherent  quality  of  cotton  is  not  adversely  affected  so  as  to  realize maximum price.
texts.text: It  is  essential  that  proper  care  is  taken  at  various  stages  of  handling  and  processing  to ensure  that  the  inherent  quality  of  cotton  is  not  adversely  affected  so  as  to  realize maximum price.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. Watering the kapas before weighment should be avoided.
texts.text: Watering the kapas before weighment should be avoided.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. Admixtures of different varieties should be avoided. The admixture of  the inferior type lowers the quality of the superior type, due to differences in the fiber quality traits.
texts.text: Admixtures of different varieties should be avoided. The admixture of  the inferior type lowers the quality of the superior type, due to differences in the fiber quality traits.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. Only  one  variety  of  cotton  should  be  heaped  and  packed  to  maintain  the  purity  and quality of the cotton.
texts.text: Only  one  variety  of  cotton  should  be  heaped  and  packed  to  maintain  the  purity  and quality of the cotton.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. For  supply  of  high  quality  of  cotton,  proper  packing  should  be  done  to  protect  from contamination and dampness.
texts.text: For  supply  of  high  quality  of  cotton,  proper  packing  should  be  done  to  protect  from contamination and dampness.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 6. Improper  drying  due  to  lack  of  proper  yard  at  village  will  generally  result  in  to  the discoloration of the fibres.
texts.text: Improper  drying  due  to  lack  of  proper  yard  at  village  will  generally  result  in  to  the discoloration of the fibres.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 7. Even  at  the  market  level,  the  conventional  packing  of  kapas  in  bales  gives  rise  to problems such as requirement of large space and possible fire hazards. Storing in open yards at the market should be avoided.
texts.text: Even  at  the  market  level,  the  conventional  packing  of  kapas  in  bales  gives  rise  to problems such as requirement of large space and possible fire hazards. Storing in open yards at the market should be avoided.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 8. The seeds from insect attacked and immature bolls being more fragile get crushed during ginning resulting in staining of lint by the oil oozing out of the cut-seeds. This oil acts as a medium for growth of the micro-organisms which will destroy the lint. So, the insect infested kapas should be separated.
texts.text: The seeds from insect attacked and immature bolls being more fragile get crushed during ginning resulting in staining of lint by the oil oozing out of the cut-seeds. This oil acts as a medium for growth of the micro-organisms which will destroy the lint. So, the insect infested kapas should be separated.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 9. Difficulties in handling of kapas due to its bulky nature - adequate storage space is to be provided both at the farmer's level as well as at the market.
texts.text: Difficulties in handling of kapas due to its bulky nature - adequate storage space is to be provided both at the farmer's level as well as at the market.

table_cells.text: Two adults or nymphs per leaf or appearance of second grade injury (yellowing in the margins of the leaves)

grid.text: Two adults or nymphs per leaf or appearance of second grade injury (yellowing in the margins of the leaves)

table_cells.text: American bollworm ( H. armigera ) and Spotted Boll worm ( E. vitella )
Five per cent damaged fruiting bodies or one larva per plant or total three damaged square per plant taken from 20 plants selected at random for counting.
Eight moths per trap per day for three consecutive days or 10 % infested flowers or bolls with live larvae.
One egg mass or skeletinized leaf ten plants

grid.text: American bollworm ( H. armigera ) and Spotted Boll worm ( E. vitella )
Five per cent damaged fruiting bodies or one larva per plant or total three damaged square per plant taken from 20 plants selected at random for counting.
Eight moths per trap per day for three consecutive days or 10 % infested flowers or bolls with live larvae.
One egg mass or skeletinized leaf ten plants
